title: Don't create `EE::Member` audit events when there is no change
description:
## Problem to solve

Right now audit events are created to whenever certain APIs are
called. This is great for maintaining visibility whenever actions
take place. However, it means that audit events are always created,
even when no change has occurred. This can cause the audit log to be
filled with events that aren't meaningful. See the screenshot on the [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8547)
for an example where no actual changed occurred, yet an event was
created.

The audit event located in the
[`EE::Members::UpdateService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/services/ee/members/update_service.rb) might exhibit this
behavior


## Proposal

When an audit event is about to be created, check that there actually
was a change. If there was, create the event if normal. However, if no
change actually occurred, do not create an audit event.

-   [x] add a spec for [`EE::Members::UpdateService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/services/ee/members/update_service.rb) to check against the described behavior
-   [x] if the spec fails, make it pass

epic.title: Don't create audit events when there is no change

title: Filtering roadmap by milestone returns "Something went wrong while fetching epics"
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

When viewing the [roadmap](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/roadmap/) for a group, attempting to filter using "milestone" shows the error "Something went wrong while fetching epics" and no data is returned. 

When looking at the network log in the browser tools, there is a GraphQL request to `roadmapGroupEpics` returning a 500 error. Taking a look at Kibana, I was able to find the error-ing request in the logs, and it looks like there's a PostgreSQL error at the root of it:

```
PG::AmbiguousColumn: ERROR:  column reference "start_date" is ambiguous
LINE 1: ...SE OR "epics"."confidential" = TRUE AND 1=0) AND (start_date...
```

### Steps to reproduce

- Pick any group that has epics in use. [GitLab.org](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org) is one I was able to replicate with!
- In the sidebar go to **Epics > Roadmap** and see some data is loaded.
- When viewing the roadmap, click in the filter / search box and select "Milestone = " and pick any milestone to filter on, I just picked 15.3 since I know that should be an active one for the GitLab group.
- See a red banner with "Something went wrong while fetching epics", and in the network tools in the browser you can see the GraphQL request has a 500.

### Example Project

I didn't make a custom project since I could replicate in any project with epics, it doesn't seem to require any specific setup.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Filtering by milestone returns an error instead of actual data.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Epics in the roadmap can be filtered by milestone, much like you can filter by label or author (and those seem to work okay currently).

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

Here's a picture of the error itself:

![GitLab.org group showing error when searching by milestone](/uploads/ca035c4a2c4042d646c69b01647c0e8c/Screen_Shot_2022-08-12_at_14.21.49.png)

This is a link to the Kibana log line for my replication showing the PostgreSQL error (accessible for GitLab team members):

https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/discover#/doc/7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090/pubsub-rails-inf-gprd-012644?id=xqRIk4IBExTeCTjeEOao

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com (hence I also removed the next two sections about application / environment checks).

### Possible fixes

Looks like it's something in the way we're doing the SQL join, so I'd guess we have to alter that to not have two things with the same column name.

title: Release N - Implement and trigger background migration
description:
Namespaces table is very wide, and used in many places, it's basically backbone of GitLab. Because it used so many times and holds much information, sometimes it contributes to the slow performance. 
Removing all the columns relating to the description of the group from the namespaces table and moving them to description-related table would make the  namespaces table slimmer and probably more performant thanks to that.

We can move some of the columns to the `namespace_settings` table or create new table to keep dedicated set of settings. I identified some columns that in my opinion are good candidates for moving. I did a quick research on each - it does not mean I'm 100% confident that the move will be easy :(.

Some of the columns, for example description-related columns, because of how wide they are - moving them will benefit performance and make this table less busy.

Right now, this is particularly visible while using 'GroupFinder' - every call to this class is loading all 49 columns of namespaces table.

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/82958 there was new table (`namespace_detailes`) implemented. To switch from using `namespaces` table columns we need to create batched migration to move the content of the namespace table's rows into the new table. 

### Implementation plan

1. Create the column in the `namespace_settings` table.
1. Setup ActiveRecord callback to keep the value up to date between `namespace` and `namespace_settings`
1. Add a special index that allows iterating over the records. (`create index i1 on namespace (id) where your_field is not null`)
1. **Implement and trigger background migration.**
1. Release N+1: Update the backend to persist the column only in the `namespace_settings` table.
1. Release N+1: Ignore the column in the `namespace` table.
1. Release N+2: Remove the column from `namespace` following our [DB guidelines](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/migration_style_guide.html#example-add-a-column-my_column-to-the-users-table).

## Availability and Testing
- Run `package-and-qa` job and evaluate results for any issues related to these database changes. Feel free to ping @vburton if there are any questions on QA test failures.

epic.title: Move description-related columns from namespace table to namespace_settings table

title: Update Vulnerability Summary counts for filtering by `cluster` and `image` filters
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work
- the summary counts on the vulnerability report should be updated when filtering by `cluster` and `image` filters


## Relevant links
- [Design Issue](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3410)
  - ![i](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/uploads/9cb7e48b1750dcdc4cc66461b495bac2/environment-vulns-default-filter.png)


## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [ ] Documentation:
- [ ] Testing:


## Implementation plan
- [x] ~backend modify `Project.vulnerabilitySeveritiesCount` to be used with `clusterAgentId` and `image`

- [ ] ~frontend modify [vulnerability_severities_count.query.graphql](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/graphql/queries/vulnerability_severities_count.query.graphql) to take `clusterAgentId` and `image` (see diffs below)

```bash
diff --git a/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/graphql/queries/vulnerability_severities_count.query.graphql b/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/graphql/queries/vulnerability_severities_count.query.graphql
index 47338b4be30..1de441b7fd3 100644
--- a/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/graphql/queries/vulnerability_severities_count.query.graphql
+++ b/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/graphql/queries/vulnerability_severities_count.query.graphql
@@ -10,6 +10,8 @@ query vulnerabilitySeveritiesCount(
   $scannerId: [VulnerabilitiesScannerID!]
   $hasIssues: Boolean
   $hasResolution: Boolean
+  $clusterAgentId: [ClustersAgentID!]
+  $image: [String!]
   $isGroup: Boolean = false
   $isProject: Boolean = false
   $isInstance: Boolean = false
@@ -53,6 +55,8 @@ query vulnerabilitySeveritiesCount(
       scannerId: $scannerId
       hasIssues: $hasIssues
       hasResolution: $hasResolution
+      clusterAgentId: $clusterAgentId
+      image: $image
     ) {
       ...VulnerabilitySeveritiesCount
     }

```

## Verification steps
1. Ensure your GDK has a ~3207279 license
1. Ensure your GDK is connected to the GitLab Runner
1. Follow [these docs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-development-kit/-/blob/main/doc/howto/kubernetes_agent.md) to set up the kubernetes agent
1. Clone [test-cis-with-agentid](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/protect/demos/sandbox/test-cis-with-agentid) and run the pipeline
1. Link the agent to a project
1. Run the pipeline to generate vulnerabilities
1. Navigate to the project/group/security center vulnerability report
1. View the vulnerabilities

title: SPIKE: Investigate lowering urgency in RemediationWorker
description:
From @dstull and I's investigation of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/365398 (SPIKE: Investigate implications for error_budget for Growth:Acquisition) we have found that most workers with `feature_category :onboarding` have `urgency :low` and only [RemediationWorker](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/workers/namespaces/free_user_cap/remediation_worker.rb) does not have `urgency :low`

From our initial research, we found that the following [elastic query](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/discover#/?_g=(filters:!(),refreshInterval:(pause:!t,value:0),time:(from:now-30d%2Fd,to:now))&_a=(columns:!(json.duration_s),filters:!(('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,index:'7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090',key:json.meta.feature_category,negate:!f,params:(query:onboarding),type:phrase),query:(match_phrase:(json.meta.feature_category:onboarding))),('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,index:'7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090',key:json.duration_s,negate:!f,type:exists,value:exists),query:(exists:(field:json.duration_s))),('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,field:json.duration_s,index:AWNABDRwNDuQHTm2tH6l,key:json.duration_s,negate:!f,params:(gte:10,lt:100),type:range),query:(range:(json.duration_s:(gte:10,lt:100))))),index:AWNABDRwNDuQHTm2tH6l,interval:auto,query:(language:kuery,query:''),sort:!(!(json.time,desc),!(json.duration_s,desc)))) revealed that `Namespaces::OnboardingPipelineCreatedWorker` and `Namespaces::OnboardingProgressWorker` are the two Sidekiq workers with a duration > 10s 

![image](/uploads/651ac1d91f32546785a10236812b99b8/image.png)


## Outcome 

No further changes required here https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370526#note_1065112551

title: Remediate slowness in GroupsProjectsController
description:
From @dstull and I's investigation of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/365398 (SPIKE: Investigate implications for error_budget for Growth:Acquisition) we have discovered some slowness in the GroupsProjectController::Create action that is causing a majority of what is taking up the allocated budget.

These findings were observed in the following [elastic query](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/discover#/?_g=(filters:!(),refreshInterval:(pause:!t,value:0),time:(from:now-15m,to:now))&_a=(columns:!(json.duration_s),filters:!(('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,index:'7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090',key:json.meta.feature_category,negate:!f,params:(query:onboarding),type:phrase),query:(match_phrase:(json.meta.feature_category:onboarding))),('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,index:'7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090',key:json.duration_s,negate:!f,type:exists,value:exists),query:(exists:(field:json.duration_s))),('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,index:'7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090',key:json.target_duration_s,negate:!f,type:exists,value:exists),query:(exists:(field:json.target_duration_s)))),index:'7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090',interval:auto,query:(language:kuery,query:''),sort:!(!(json.time,desc)))).

We already have an issue open to [Simplify Group and Project creation - Experiment Promotion
](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/339998), as this is related this is worth mentioning.

From our preliminary research, the slowness looks to be like it is coming from either `Groups::CreateService` or `Projects::CreateService`

---

With the [applied filters](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/discover#/?_a=(columns:!(json.status,json.meta.caller_id,json.duration_s,json.target_duration_s),filters:!(('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,key:json.subcomponent,negate:!t,params:(query:graphql_json),type:phrase),query:(match_phrase:(json.subcomponent:(query:graphql_json)))),('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,key:json.meta.feature_category,negate:!f,params:!(experimentation_conversion,experimentation_expansion,onboarding),type:phrases),query:(bool:(minimum_should_match:1,should:!((match_phrase:(json.meta.feature_category:experimentation_conversion)),(match_phrase:(json.meta.feature_category:experimentation_expansion)),(match_phrase:(json.meta.feature_category:onboarding)))))),('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,index:'7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090',key:json.meta.caller_id,negate:!f,params:(query:'Registrations::GroupsProjectsController%23create%09'),type:phrase),query:(match_phrase:(json.meta.caller_id:'Registrations::GroupsProjectsController%23create%09'))),('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,field:json.duration_s,index:'7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090',key:json.duration_s,negate:!f,params:(gte:1,lt:100),type:range),query:(range:(json.duration_s:(gte:1,lt:100)))),('$state':(store:appState),meta:(alias:!n,disabled:!f,index:'7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090',key:json.duration_s,negate:!t,params:(query:0),type:phrase),query:(match_phrase:(json.duration_s:0)))),index:'7092c4e2-4eb5-46f2-8305-a7da2edad090',interval:auto,query:(language:kuery,query:''),sort:!(!(json.time,desc)))&_g=(filters:!(),refreshInterval:(pause:!t,value:0),time:(from:now-24h%2Fh,to:now))) in our logs, we can see around `1,173` hits - we expect this number to drop down once https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/95629 is merged

title: Audit event streaming for issue and epic deletion
description:
## Problem

There is way to get visibility into who deletes work items and when. 

In the words of a customer:

> Various reporting systems are querying Gitlab issues and epics. However, at the moment there is no way to detect when an issue or epic is deleted. This means a) we end up with old data in reports and don't know to remove it unless we requery every single issue/epic (bad!), b) if a user deletes information permanently, we don't know who did it, which means we can't hold people accountable for that.

## Proposal

Add streaming audit events for work item deletion. This should be retrofitted to legacy issues and epics if possible. 

the `message` attribute should contain the `Title`, `IID`, and maybe the `ID` of the work item.

## Audit Event Guide

https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/audit_event_guide/

### Release Notes

Before this release, there was no way to easily get visibility into who deleted an issue or epic and when. Issue and epic deletion events are now sent to your configured audit streaming destination and include important information such as the individual taking the action and issue/epic title, id, iid, and project so you can maintain a historical record of issue and epic deletion activity. 

https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/audit_event_streaming.html

title: Deploy freeze time period logic does not apply congruently with cron schedules
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "type::bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=type::bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

When configuring [Deploy freezes](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/releases/index.html#prevent-unintentional-releases-by-setting-a-deploy-freeze), the `Freeze start` time doesn't always apply as expected in alignment with how [cron syntax](https://crontab.guru/) is normally interpreted. The behavior outlined in this issue is present on GitLab.com SaaS and GitLab Omnibus 15.2.2.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a job within a project's `.gitlab-ci.yml` file that should not run during deploy freeze periods. We can simply use the example in the [documentation here](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/releases/index.html#prevent-unintentional-releases-by-setting-a-deploy-freeze):

    ```yaml
    deploy_to_production:
      stage: deploy
      script: deploy_to_prod.sh
      rules:
    - if: $CI_DEPLOY_FREEZE == null
    ```

1. [Configure a deploy freeze period](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/releases/index.html#prevent-unintentional-releases-by-setting-a-deploy-freeze) on the project matching the following examples (with any suitable adjustments for the current time when testing).

1. Try to trigger/create new pipelines - you'll notice that the deploy freeze will not apply in all cases of valid cron syntax usage for the freeze period.

4. For the examples below, the current date/time of testing is `Thu Aug 11 08:00:00 UTC 2022` and we try to configure a variety of different freeze start times, which behave accordingly:

    - **Not working - _jobs that should be subject to the deploy freeze will run anyway_** 
        1. Freeze start `* * * 8 *` & freeze end `* * * 10 *`
            - The expectation is that the freeze start would trigger [“At every minute in August.”](https://crontab.guru/#*_*_*_8_*), which covers the current time period, and would continue to trigger for every remaining minute in the month of August. The end time is [“At every minute in October.”](https://crontab.guru/#*_*_*_10_*) so we're still within the deploy freeze period.

        1. Freeze start `1 9 * 8 *` & freeze end `* * * 10 *`
            - The expectation is that the freeze start would apply from ["09:01 in August.”](https://crontab.guru/#1_9_*_8_*) and end [“At every minute in October.”](https://crontab.guru/#*_*_*_10_*). The start time has already passed, and we should still currently be within the deploy freeze period before it ends.

        1. Freeze start `1 9 * 8 1` & freeze end `* * * 10 *`
            - The expectation is that the freeze start would apply ["At 09:01 on Mondays in August”](https://crontab.guru/#1_9_*_8_1) and end [“At every minute in October.”](https://crontab.guru/#*_*_*_10_*). The start time has already passed, and we should still currently be within the deploy freeze period before it ends.

    - **Does work - _jobs that should be subject to the deploy freeze will _not_ run_**

        1. Freeze start `* * * 7 *` & Freeze end `* * * 10 *`
            - The expectation is that the freeze start would trigger ["At every minute in July.”](https://crontab.guru/#*_*_*_7_*) and end [“At every minute in October.”](https://crontab.guru/#*_*_*_10_*). The start time has already passed, and we should still currently be within the deploy freeze period before it ends.

        1. Freeze start `1 9 1 8 *` & Freeze end `* * * 10 *`
            - The expectation is that the freeze start would apply from ["09:01 on day-of-month 1 in August.”](https://crontab.guru/#1_9_1_8_*) and end [“At every minute in October.”](https://crontab.guru/#*_*_*_10_*). The start time has already passed, and we should still currently be within the deploy freeze period before it ends.

### Example Project

An example `.gitlab-ci.yml` file used for testing is available here:
- https://gitlab.com/jamesreed/deployfreeze-cron-demo/-/blob/567474203fa94d15ceeda839d6af4164b8fbe0e8/.gitlab-ci.yml

Example pipeline runs that were created after setting each of the aforementioned freeze periods can be found here:
- https://gitlab.com/jamesreed/deployfreeze-cron-demo/-/pipelines


### What is the current *bug* behavior?

When configuring [Deploy freezes](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/releases/index.html#prevent-unintentional-releases-by-setting-a-deploy-freeze), the `Freeze start` time doesn't always apply as expected, depending on the [cron syntax](https://crontab.guru/) that has been used to set the freeze period.

It's as though the `Freeze start` will only apply if the cron syntax specifies a time period that won't repeat "within" the specified freeze period, relative to the current time.

For example - Freeze start `* * * 7 *` to start ["At every minute in July.”](https://crontab.guru/#*_*_*_7_*) & Freeze end `* * * 10 *` [“At every minute in October.”](https://crontab.guru/#*_*_*_10_*) will work when we're currently in August, and relative to the current time (August) this is a time that has absolutely passed already upon the first check of this syntax, and the freeze start won't repeat between now and the end time.

The common factor in the examples that don't work as expected seems to be that the freeze start will trigger multiple times before the freeze end time is reached, or more specifically it's that the [next freeze end time _will not_ be triggered _before_ the next freeze start time](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/ci/freeze_period_status.rb#L30), so we aren't considered as being "within the freeze period".

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Deploy freeze times should work congruently to the defined cron syntax. I believe all of the examples mentioned in this issue _should_ work but currently don't.

### Possible fixes

- The [freeze period logic](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/models/ci/freeze_period_status.rb#L15-L31) may need to be modified so that the different variations of cron schedules used to set the freeze period can work as expected.

- There are a couple of open issues that could potentially address this behavior if they're implemented in a way that limits the possible freeze period configuration to those that we know will work as intended.

    - [Deploy freeze: show human-readable Cron messages](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/212458/)
    - [Specify specific non-recurring date for deploy freeze](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/247110)

Either simplify the spec or remove it

title: Arbitrary GFM references rendered in Jira issue description leak private/confidential resources
description:
**[HackerOne report #1653149](https://hackerone.com/reports/1653149)** by `yvvdwf` on 2022-07-28, assigned to @ngeorge1:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

Hi,

Gitlab allows integrating Jira issues whose descriptions are rendered using GFM. However the descriptions are not redacted. Consequently the priviate/confidential information are leaked to unauthorized users.

This report is basically the same as [the previous report](https://hackerone.com/reports/1652853). They are the same model of exploitation but their root causes are different. Indeed the Jira descriptions are managed by `JiraGfmPipeline` pipeline.


###  Steps to reproduce:

Requirements:

- access to a premium subscription (no problem on GitLab.com as there are free trials, they work great for the attack)  
- a Jira server. I used a cloud Jira instance on atlassian.com

As a normal user (victim):

- create a private project, let's call `victim/project-a`,  then create a confidential issue inside. It's GFM reference is now `victim/project-a#1`

As an attacker which has a premium subscription (e.g., via free trials):

- In an existing project or create a new one  
- Go to `Settings/Integrations` and select `Jira`. Follow the [guide](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/integration/jira/issues.html#view-jira-issues) to fill the form to enable viewing Jira issues in the project.  
- Login Jira, create an issue on the dashboard by fillting `victim/project-a#1` into the `Description` textbox.  
- Go back to Gitlab web to view the issue you've created, .e.g., in `Issues/Jira issues` then select the issue  
- Right click on the link of `victim/project-a#1` to view its source code. You should see the title of the issue created by the victim.  
- Below is an example when I used `gitlab-org/gitlab#363725` as payload which is used to track one of my H1 reports.

![jira-pipeline.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/6d32746b-ae58-4f72-8fbb-dc17c3c88179/jira-pipeline.png)

###  Impact

This vulnerability allows to renders *all* GFM references, such as, merged requests, issues, etc, even if they are private or confidential.

For example, attackers can simply scan through all *issue* numbers (starting from 1) of the `gitlab-org/gitlab` project, and thus leaking their titles.

Best regards,  
yvvdwf

####  Impact

This vulnerability allows attacker to access to *all private or confidential* GFM references, such as, merged requests, issues, etc.

For example, attackers can simply scan through all issue numbers (starting from 1) of the `gitlab-org/gitlab` project, and thus leaking their titles.

####  Impact

This vulnerability allows attacker to access to *all private or confidential* GFM references, such as, merged requests, issues, etc.

For example, attackers can simply scan through all issue numbers (starting from 1) of the `gitlab-org/gitlab` project, and thus leaking their titles.

## Attachments

title: Tech debt: Update implementation of PBKDF2+SHA512 user password hashing implies it is the default when it is not
description:
## Problem


Risks for GitLab.com ~security , and availability :
 
1. There is risk of enabling `pbkdf2_password_encryption_write` by accident in GitLab.com when we want to retain BCrypt
2. https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/security/password_storage.html#password-storage says BCrypt is default
3. Because feature flags are enabled by default in test, we are testing for `PBKDF2+SHA512`, and not for BCrypt.

## Proposal

1. Remove the read feature flag so that any GitLab instance can read BCrypt or PBKDF2+SHA512 passwords without issues.
1. Refactor the code so it doesn't look like PBKDF2+SHA512 is the default mechanism. We should allow the write strategy to change depending on application config, or FIPS enabled.

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/367147#note_1035749346


/cc @dblessing @nmalcolm @stanhu @jarka @hsutor

title: Show approval comment after deployment is approved
description:
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently in BETA, details on the **release post item generator** can be found in the handbook:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg. The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. --> 

### Release notes

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

You can now see the comments left by users when reviewing a deployment, providing more context as to why manual job was approved or rejected. This functionality is also useful for organisations in highly regulated industries that need to audit release events.

### Problem to solve 

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

As a development team member, I can view the reason for an approved or rejected deployment in the UI, after an approval is given, so I understand the why the reviewer made their decision.

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager)

-->

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses?
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ -->

The user should be able to view the comment from a reviewer about their approval or rejection decision for a deployment job.

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

- In the Environment detail page, display the thumbs up button if the deployment and associated protected environment requires approvals, which opens up the pop-up
  - After the deployment is approved by all required approvers, the thumbs up button is still present for the deployment. Clicking this button opens up the pop-up with the history of approval and comments.

title: [Feature flag] Enable inline build hook execution
description:
## Summary

This issue is to rollout [inline execution of build hooks](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/366755) on production,
that is currently behind the `execute_build_hooks_inline` feature flag.

This enables the computation of web-hook payloads when the events are triggered, and not when they are consumed from the by the job-hooks worker.

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::integrations" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_ecosystem_integrations`
- Best individual to reach out to: @alexkalderimis 
- PM: @g.hickman 

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

We expect the number of occasions where stale data is seen in pipeline build hooks to decrease.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Resource consumption in pipeline workers (especially the pipeline finished worker) could become unacceptable.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

- [Sidekiq overview dashboard](https://dashboards.gitlab.net/d/sidekiq-main/sidekiq-overview?orgId=1)

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

Production errors are not anticipated, but any errors would include reference to the `Ci::Build.execute_hooks` method.

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status f6c5c15d`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set execute_build_hooks_inline true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status f6c5c15d`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com execute_build_hooks_inline true`
- [x] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/366755) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [x] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [x] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set execute_build_hooks_inline <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set execute_build_hooks_inline <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set execute_build_hooks_inline true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/366755) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).


### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a [merge request](gitlab-org/gitlab!95712) to remove `execute_build_hooks_inline` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [x] Close [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/366755) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete execute_build_hooks_inline --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [x] Create a follow-up issue to remove the worker https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/370387#note_1057860468.
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set execute_build_hooks_inline false
```

title: Recreate Redis Counters using Snowplow events - Phase 2: Wave 5b -FE EVENTS
description:
## Summary

In https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7493, we instrumented the first set of Redis Counters using Snowplow events in SaaS. This is the 5th wave of counters to be instrumented using Snowplow Events. Splitting this counter, [redis_hll_counters.epics_usage.epics_usage_total_unique_counts_monthly](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/config/metrics/counts_28d/20210216174929_g_analytics_valuestream_monthly.yml), into its own issue per [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/362281#note_1015083321) since the counter is made up of many sub-metrics.

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/366827, the backend events needed for  [redis_hll_counters.epics_usage.epics_usage_total_unique_counts_monthly](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/config/metrics/counts_28d/20210216174929_g_analytics_valuestream_monthly.yml) were instrumented. This issue is for a single FRONTEND event which is needed to ship this counter.


Submetric that needs to be migrated:
1. [ ] g_project_management_users_epic_issue_added_from_epic [**FRONTEND EVENT**]

title: Preload and cache the Task when hovering a link in the tasks list
description:
Currently, we start loading the task only when the task modal is open. We could improve UX by pre-loading the work item on hover: when the user hovers the task link for more than 150 ms, we start fetching the data, and then we populate the modal with task data immediately.

Also, it would be nice to have the task cached after we fetched it for the first time.

title: Don't create user set to awaiting audit events when there is no change
description: ## Problem to solve Right now audit events are created to whenever certain APIs are called. This is great for maintaining visibility whenever actions take place. However, it means that audit events are always created, even when no change has occurred. This can cause the audit log to be filled with events that aren't meaningful. See the screenshot on the [epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/8547) for an example where no actual changed occurred, yet an event was created. The audit event located in the [`Members::AwaitService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/services/members/await_service.rb) might exhibit this behavior ## Proposal When an audit event is about to be created, check that there actually was a change. If there was, create the event if normal. However, if no change actually occurred, do not create an audit event. - [x] add a spec for [`Members::AwaitService`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/services/members/await_service.rb) to check against the described behavior - [x] if the spec fails, make it pass

epic.title: Don't create audit events when there is no change

title: Cleanup `chat_name_token`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Experiment Name] Successful Cleanup -->

## Summary

In the https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/91991, we renamed the `chat_names.service_id` to `integration_id`. That introduced a small change inside `lib/gitlab/chat_name_token.rb`.

* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/91991#note_1019238226
* https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/91991#note_1055958023

## Proposal

Updating the `lib/gitlab/chat_name_token.rb` with the following:
```ruby
def get
  Gitlab::Redis::SharedState.with do |redis|
    data = redis.get(redis_shared_state_key)
    Gitlab::Json.parse(data, symbolize_names: true) if data
  end
end

```

## Steps
- cleanup the newly added code in upcoming releases (e.g. 16.0)

title: Refactor {Hooks,HookLogs}Controller concerns
description:
The following discussion from !94145 should be addressed:

- [ ] @.luke started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/94145#note_1054852522):  (+1 comment)

    > **Thought**
    > 
    > There's a lot of duplication in the three "hook logs" controllers now - `{Groups,Projects,Admin}::HookLogsControllers`. 
    > 
    > This module that's being included, `Integrations::HooksExecution` is actually designed to de-duplicate logic in the "hook" controllers `{Groups,Projects,Admin}::HooksControllers` - but we also oddly are including it in the "hook logs" controllers too! I think the reason is just to call the `#set_hook_execution_notice` method that's defined in that module, but nothing else?!
    > 
    > I think it's best to keep this exactly as it is for now, because I can see a couple of extra steps to clean this up (not your code - existing code!) before we come to de-duplicating the "hook logs" controllers. 
    > 
    > This is what I think should happen:
    > 
    > 1. We remove `Integrations::HooksExecution` from being included in the "hook logs" controllers, because, the methods in that are for the "hook" controllers. 
    > 2. We put `#set_hook_execution_notice` into its own module, and include just that into the "hook" and "hook logs" controllers
    > 3. We create a new module, in a similar vein to `HooksExecution`, for the "hook logs" controllers to dry them up.
    > 
    > :point_up: All of this should be a follow-up, and I think what you have here is correct for now! I'll create a follow-up issue for this ~"maintenance::refactor" and I'm happy to work on this after the MR merges.

With `:work_items_hierarchy` on, create a public issue. 2. Make it confidential 3. Click "Add a task" from the hierarchy widget. 4. Add a title, click "Create task" ### Example Project ### What is the current *bug* behavior? ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info

`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:

#### Results of GitLab application Check

title: Vulnerability Report: Activity filter menu changes
description: ## Why are we doing this work The `Activity` menu on our [Vulnerability Report](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-examples/security/security-reports/-/security/vulnerability_report/) is confusing with the how `All Activity`, `No Activity`, `With issues`, and `No longer detected` are seemingly tied together. This issue is to rewrite the menu so that each filter group is an independent OR condition. 1. User can select options from as many groups as they wish. 2. User can select only one option from each group (eg: either `Still detected` or `No longer detected` can be checked, but not both). 3. Clicking a selected option will deselect and remove that group from the query. 4. Unselecting all options will reset the default with `All Activity` checked. 5. Clicking `All Activity` will reset and uncheck all options. ~backend confirmed the current GraphQL query supports the parameters and structure we need. See https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/7883#note_954189436 Currently supported filters: 1. Detection - Still detected - No longer detected 2. Issue - Has issue - Does not have issue 3. MR - Has MR - Does not have MR 4. Solution Available - Is available - Is not available 5. False Positive - Is a false positive - Is not a false positive ## Relevant links ## Non-functional requirements - [ ] Documentation: - [ ] Feature flag: - [ ] Performance: - [ ] Testing: ## Implementation plan The current API supports the following features for filtering: | Backend supports | Feature | Filter | | ------ | ------ | ------ | | Available | Detection | `state` | | Available | Issue | `hasIssues` | | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/371313 | MR | - | | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/358638 | Solution Available | - | | N/A | False positive | - | | Available | Auto Resolved | `hasResolution` | | N/A | Auto Dismissed | - | Based on this table, we should implement whatever is implementable. - [ ] Modify https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/components/shared/filters/activity_filter.vue to match the design ## E2E testing This involves front end and backend changes for activity filter. Calls for adding at least one E2E test. ## Verification steps

epic.title: Additional Activity filters for Vulnerability Reports

title: Improve Hierarchy for Deployments Navigation
description:
## Release notes

We have updated the navigation so that now when you click on the Deployments tab, you will go to the Environments page to find your Environments and Deployments, as opposed to the previous Feature Flags page. We have also updated the ordering of the Deployments menu items so that Environments is the top item which is more intuitive.

## Summary

Currently, when a user clicks on Deployments on the side navigation, they land on Feature Flags. Understandably, this is because Feature Flags is the first section within Deployments, but it would probably make more sense for the hierarchy here to follow the experience through the Release Stage. New users might get confused as to why deployments automatically drops them into Feature Flags. It doesn't seem like this list is alphabetical either, as Environments is below Feature Flags. 

<details><summary>Screenshot</summary>
![Screen_Shot_2022-08-09_at_4.19.00_PM](/uploads/a3159372eb2b8901f82ed1f1104913f0/Screen_Shot_2022-08-09_at_4.19.00_PM.png)
</details>

Inspired by our Release Stage Brainstorm session on how to increase Release SMAU.

## Proposal

- [ ] Move the "Environments" up in navigation instead of "Feature flags"
- [ ] Make "Deployments" navigation item to lead to the "Enviroments" index page by default

title: Partitioning Tooling: Add helper for finding duplicate index definitions
description:
In order to rename indexes between tables, which is needed when migrating a table to be it's own first partition, we need to match indexes by their definitions.

This does not work when there are duplicate indexes, same definition, different names.

We need to add a helper that finds duplicate indexes so we can drop them in a migration, prevent adding them in future, and prevent index renaming when a duplicate condition exists.

epic.title: Add tools to support ci partitioning

title: Partitioning Tooling: Add helper for renaming indexes between tables
description:
When partitioning tables, it will be a common requirement to make a table it's own first partition, and as part of that, we need to rename indexes after postgres automatically renames them.

We need a helper that can inspect the `pg_indexes` catalog, matching indexes by their definitions, between two tables, and fix their names.

epic.title: Add tools to support ci partitioning

title: Forked repositories do not deduplicate LFS objects
description:
Currently, GitLab is able to deduplicate forked repositories to save on storage costs by using shared pool repositories. (Note, there is a bug in measurement which is being fixed here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/368150#note_1054628587) Unfortunately, this functionality does not apply to LFS objects today.

We should handle LFS objects ideally similarly to repository storage:

1. We should only measure the _changed_ LFS objects of the new project to count against their storage limit
1. We should ideally deduplicate the actual stored LFS content, so we do not replicate it for every fork. This could also accelerate the process of forking, along with reducing cost. (Similar to pool repositories)


##### How others handle LFS

It looks like GitHub attributes the forked project's changed LFS objects back to the parent project: https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/working-with-files/managing-large-files/collaboration-with-git-large-file-storage. I'm not entirely sure why, perhaps related to how they charge for LFS.

title: Reduce Namespace::AggregationSchedule lease
description:
# Background

3 years ago, `Namespace::RootStorageStatistics` was added to GitLab to track storage statistics at the root namespace level, for all groups and projects nested within.

With the implementation of this class, a namespace's statistics are updated asynchronously with a lease, which is currently [set to 1.5 hours](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/63ff715f506b63d24c4cd078d31be3bae807ecb4/app/models/namespace/aggregation_schedule.rb#L9).

This means that there can be a delay of statistic updates at the root namespace level of up to 1.5 hours after a change has been made.

The approach taken for this class and it's updates are well reasoned and documented in https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/namespaces_storage_statistics.html

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369091 we investigated/discussed whether we could reduce this lease.

# Proposal

As [discussed here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369091#note_1050114953), the proposal is to gradually reduce the lease until we can remove it entirely.

1. Week 1: The lease is reduced to 1h, performance is observed
1. Week 2: If nothing comes up, the lease is reduced to .5h, performance is observed
1. Week 3: If nothing comes up, the lease is removed

_Note: these are merely ballpark timing suggestions, they can be adjusted if necessary_

# Additional notes

- We should make use of feature flags to control this effort so that if a negative impact is observed we can quickly and easily revert the lease reduction
- We should identify metrics to monitor so we can effectively determine if the lease reduction has been successful or not
- Before the lease can be removed entirely, we should ensure the worker is idempotent, as noted [in this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369091#note_1054281166).
- As we approach removing the lease, a dedicated queue could be created for this, allowing the sidekiq jobs to be executed by a specific infra fleet. You may need to talk with someone from Scalability about this
- We can consider using deduplication and read-only replicas to improve performance, more details are here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/369091#note_1054281166

title: Delete browserker images using Auto Delete
description:
## Problem to solve

When an MR is created or updated within the [browserker](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker) project, two docker images are created to run the end-to-end tests against. Once the tests are complete, those two docker images should be deleted.

This cleanup task doesn't always work which can leave images hanging around taking up disk space

## Proposed Solution

Update the browserker project to use the [auto delete](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/settings/packages_and_registries) functionality within packages and registry. 

## Implementation plan

- [x] `build branch` and `build future` tasks should also create a container that includes a keyword to make them easily identifiable by the delete job. One possibility could be `testing-mr-image`. For example `registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/lint-fixs-MR-TESTING-7f74f677ddf8ce414cc0c6e236f4a073856f0e7f`
- [x] Update [auto delete](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/browserker/-/settings/packages_and_registries) so that containers including the word `MR-TESTING` are deleted after one day
- [ ] ~~Update the end-to-end test to reference the new image when testing~~
- [ ] ~~Stop creating the original images as they should no longer be used~~
- [x] remove the clean-up script and step
- [x] clean up any old images left behind by the old process

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of `ci_forked_source_public_cost_factor`
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346400) on production,
that is currently behind the `ci_forked_source_public_cost_factor` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: Pipeline Execution
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_pipeline_execution`
- Best individual to reach out to: @allison.browne
- PM: @jheimbuck_gl

## Stakeholders


## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

We expect that .008 will be applied to forked source projects that are public and forked from a public project.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Projects not expected to could get the factor. Errors could crop up.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?
### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/discover#/?_g=h@89714be&_a=h@85806c8


## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] Main MR: `/chatops run auto_deploy status 3aafd765cdab120a7b02caad4b03ffd8ec595d7d`
      - https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CB2S7NNDP/p1661274046272569
    - [x] New logging: `/chatops run auto_deploy status 14cf2a5b1dbf5d183288727d82230f44bce28953`
    - [x]  https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CB2S7NNDP/p1661355040410989
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_forked_source_public_cost_factor true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status 3aafd765cdab120a7b02caad4b03ffd8ec595d7d`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com ci_forked_source_public_cost_factor true`
- [x] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [-] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [-] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
  -   - not applicable since this wont change behavior
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346400) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [-] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [-] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_pipeline_execution`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [-] `/chatops run feature set ci_forked_source_public_cost_factor <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [-] `/chatops run feature set ci_forked_source_public_cost_factor <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set ci_forked_source_public_cost_factor true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/346400) that the feature has been globally enabled.

title: Add toggle between legacy and new Web IDE
description:
## Problem to solve

As we develop the new Web IDE, we want to get feedback early from both internal and external sources. Putting the new Web IDE experience behind a feature flag allows us to have the new codebase in the main GitLab project early on, but for those who have the feature flag enabled, they may be left with an incomplete editing experience.

## Proposal

- Add a toggle in the User’s preference page to switch to the legacy Web IDE. The new Web IDE is enabled by default once we turn on the feature flag.
- Display a user callout enticing the user to try the new Web IDE on the project’s overview page. The user callout should only appear once.
  * The goal is just to get users to try it out, not to communicate critical information about the status or how to switch back
  * The critical information already shows up as soon as users open it, no matter from which place
  * Overloading the UI with this in different places could feel like advertisement Once dismissed, or if the user already visited the Web IDE, it should also not pop up again.
- Create a welcome page in the new Web IDE that displays a link to the User’s preferences page where the user can turn off the new Web IDE.

| User preferences | New Web IDE callout box | Web IDE Welcome screen |
|------------------|-------------------------|------------------------|
| ![user_preferences_switch](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/dbd3e669214da6c0a31dffa7fb69fbee/user_preferences_switch.png) | ![new_web_ide_callout](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/6d6be2a5bc4fd3a0fe48bec1ab201364/new_web_ide_callout.png) | ![new_web_ide_welcome_screen](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/05f83f5b0d86a05850193b59b273482f/new_web_ide_welcome_screen.png) |

### Feature rollout

We will follow a phased rollout approach where we will incrementally enable the new Web IDE in gitlab.com. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process for more information.

### Instrumentation

Until we have full instrumentation of the new Web IDE, we should at least collect a snowplow event that indicates how many users have interacted with the toggle and tried the new Web IDE.

## Questions

1. Can we do this on a user level? Or would it have to be at a project/group level?

title: Add GLM values for trials started from free user registration
description:
# summary 
We're currently unable to monitor trials started from the free registration experience. It's important that we monitor this experience and understand how many users are starting trials during this experience and how successful they are in their trials. 
 
# Solution
If a user starts a trial via the free registration experience by turning "on" the trial toggle on the company page then we should apply the following GLM values and ensure that these values are stored. 
 
Location: 
* The values below should be added when a user selects to start a trial during free registration process. The URL of this page is `https://gitlab.com/users/sign_up/company/new` with additional query parameters for `jobs_to_be_done_other`, `=&`registration_objective`=move_repository&` and `role`. Example full URL `https://gitlab.com/users/sign_up/company/new?jobs_to_be_done_other=&registration_objective=move_repository&role=software_developer`
* 

**Values to add:**
  
GLM_SOURCE = `about.gitlab.com`
GLM_CONTENT = `free-user-registration`
 
Note these values should only be submitted if the trial toggle is placed in the 'on' position: 
 
![image](/uploads/89120d2a2564f0338ed7cb4a72611de4/image.png)

epic.title: Improve GLM collection for SaaS trials

title: Add glm_source and glm_content params to free trial signup experience
description:
# Summary
We're currently dropping GLM URL parameters in the new registration experience. For example, as a test I signed up for a SaaS trial from the marketing home page which includes the follow GLM parameters `https://gitlab.com/-/trial_registrations/new?glm_source=about.gitlab.com&glm_content=default-saas-trial`. I created a trial with the following user/namespace: user_id: 12218743 group_id: 56312717. However, my GLM data is not present in the `customers_db_trial_histories` table. 
 
During testing I noticed that after landing back in the registration experience after confirming my email the GLM fields were no longer present in the URL. I believe these parameters previously followed the user through the signup experience and we captured the values when the submitted the trial form or when the trial was applied to a specific group. 
 
# Solution
We should ensure that the GLM data is being captured when a user signups for a trial.

epic.title: Improve GLM collection for SaaS trials

title: Feature flag rollout - import_export_web_upload_stream
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the development feature](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93379) on production,
that is currently behind the `import_export_web_upload_stream` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: Group::Import
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_manage_import`
- Best individual to reach out to: @rodrigo.tomonari 
- PM: @iganbaruch 

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## Expectations

This feature flag will enable an improved method to upload the project tarball file to an external URL.

The new approach is described in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/93379

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Uploads to external websites will fail, and exceptions will be logged

- Invalid response code while uploading file. Code: XXX
- Invalid response code while downloading file. Code: XXX

The feature flag won't need to be turned off. We can analyze what went wrong if the new code and fix it forward.

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->
_Consider mentioning checks for 5xx errors or other anomalies like an increase in redirects 
(302 HTTP response status)_

### What can we check for monitoring production after rollouts?

_Consider adding links to check for Sentry errors, Production logs for 5xx, 302s, etc._

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev --staging --staging-ref`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.
      The best environment to validate the feature in is [staging-canary](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/#staging-canary)
      as this is the first environment deployed to. Note you will need to make sure you are configured to use canary as outlined [here](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/environments/canary-stage/)
      when accessing the staging environment in order to make sure you are testing appropriately.

### Specific rollout on production

- Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- If you're using [project-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab,gitlab-org/gitlab-foss,gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [group-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --group=gitlab-org,gitlab-com <feature-flag-name> true`
- If you're using [user-actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), you must enable the feature on these entries:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --user=<your-username> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Verify that the feature works on the specific entries. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before global rollout

- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com. 
- [x] Ensure that any breaking changes have been announced following the [release post process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#deprecations-removals-and-breaking-changes) to ensure GitLab customers are aware.
- [x] Notify `#support_gitlab-com` and your team channel ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)).

### Global rollout on production

For visibility, all `/chatops` commands that target production should be executed in the `#production` slack channel and cross-posted (with the command results) to the responsible team's slack channel (`#g_TEAM_NAME`).

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --random`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the default-enabling MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [ ] Consider cleaning up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel. Otherwise these settings may override the default enabled.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can [create a separate issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

You can either [create a follow-up issue for Feature Flag Cleanup](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/new?issuable_template=Feature%20Flag%20Cleanup) or use the checklist below in this same issue.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the cleanup MR has been included in the release package.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the monthly release was tagged](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run release check <merge-request-url> <milestone>`
- [x] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] If not already done, clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev --staging --staging-ref --production`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set import_export_web_upload_stream false

title: Adjust max seat copy during active trial
description:
# Problem 

After we enable the 5-user limit (enforcement is turned on) a free namespace will receive the following copy when visiting the usage quota page.
 
![image](/uploads/b7b6cde0b1e7606ad29d2d78cb9a58ae/image.png)
 
However, if the namespace starts a trial they are shown the standard paid experience, which includes `Max Seats Used` `Seats Owed` `Add seats`. While these values and CTA are very helpful to paying customers they can be confusing to a namespace in a trial as they've never seen these terms before, and they will never have a value in the `Seats Owed` during a trial. 
 
![image](/uploads/c9f27bf1010beb0625fd306b3c04d574/image.png)
 
# Solution
 
We should update the copy presented in the free namespace enforcement experience to utilize it during the trial experience as well, something along the lines of:
 
Title: Unlimited members during your trial

Body: To ensure all members can access the group when your trial ends, you can upgrade to a paid tier.

CTA: Explore paid plans
 
![image](/uploads/0f7ac3c200e46f7e826b221b4f415541/image.png)

title: API to import gist with one file to a project or user's namespace
description:
## Problem to solve
We can import repos from GitHub, but for a complete migration away from GitHub, we would need to have a way to import GitHub Gists, too.

With the release of [Snippets with multiple Files](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/14340), it is now possible to migrate GitLab Gists (up to 10 files) directly into Snippets.

## Proposal 
This is MVC , we will create API that import gists with one file only, to the user's namespace or a project. 

If the gist is public in GH, make it public in GitLab, if it is secret in GH, make it private on GitLab.

description:
As part of the feature flag rollout in production for the new license compliance MR widget https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/367703
I discovered a small un-released bug in production when a user is not a admin level role. No URL is provided to the frontend when you cannot manage a license, which makes sense.

The fix is is to not show the `Manage Licenses` button in the MR widget when a user does not have the correct permissions. The button would show but without a valid link. It was a no-op when you had the incorrect permission level.
